confession.seduction_context: during time of her last husband by whom she was so badly treated that she despaired
sabbat_activities: making hail to spoil grain crop at Easter

testimony.quarrel_subject: refused to relinquish guard of 'la harde des fosses' in favor of accused and her husband
owed Catherine a resal of wheat as rent for a field; it had been seized by Colas Avereu to settle Catherine's debt to him, but Catherine still pressed them for payment
seized wheat from Claudon George to pay debt accused owed him (3 bichots)
his horse strayed into field of wheat where Catherine was reaping
testimony.threat_quote: Que c'estoit moult mal faict, de gaster ainsi le bien de dieu

testimony.quarrel_subject: accused asked for wool from sheep for 'un bas de chausse'; witness refused saying she kept the sheep for a master and must manage them as carefully as bees
Catherine's husband helped with hay harvest; she came to ask for day's pay, but witness said her husband owed him money and they needed to reckon up
Catherine asked for loan of horse to bring fruit from village of Malreanneix; he refused because had too much work carting from fields
Catherine helped him reap and insisted on being paid with the largest of seven piglets; he gave her a middling one instead

harms_alleged.target: largest piglet and two next largest
harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: as soon as she had taken the piglet

testimony.quarrel_subject: foal belonging to her son got into his field; he chased it out saying 'qu'au diable soit le poulain et son maitre'
refused to sell the accused some oats

harms_alleged.target: fine cow and two calves it was carrying

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: after accused's son left lease of another cow

timeline.subject: Catherine Malremmeix
timeline.details: informations preparatoires against Catherine, widow of Claude Malreannaix of Saint Margarée, accused by Laurence, wife of George Tolbay

timeline.subject: Catherine Malremmeix
timeline.details: First interrogation; she denied all charges, said she was about 45, widow of Claude Malremmeix, currently married to Mauriche Harauze who went to war

timeline.subject: Catherine Malremmeix
timeline.details: Confrontations with witnesses; made no objection to any witness, agreed their stories but denied witchcraft

timeline.subject: Catherine Malremmeix
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves question extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Catherine Malremmeix
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture; racked; confessed to attending sabbat, being seduced by Mre Persin, killing animals, attending sabbat on mountain of Ramberg, making hail at Easter

timeline.subject: Catherine Malremmeix
timeline.details: Further interrogation; confirmed some confessions, withdrew several accusations

timeline.subject: Catherine Malremmeix
timeline.details: Death sentence from Change de Nancy

timeline.subject: Catherine Malremmeix
timeline.details: Further confirmation of confessions and accusations

accomplices_named.name: la Stablatte
accomplices_named.context: first in the dance at sabbat

accomplices_named.name: wife of Colas Cui
accomplices_named.context: third in the dance at sabbat

accomplices_named.name: Mathieu Blaise
accomplices_named.context: present at sabbat on mountain of Ramberg

accomplices_named.name: Demenge Simonel
accomplices_named.context: present at sabbat; later retracted 'par haine'

accomplices_named.name: wife of Peu de Cuyr, dite Podecatte
accomplices_named.context: present at sabbat; maintained accusation when confronted in prison

accomplices_named.name: Jehennon widow of Peu de Cuyr
accomplices_named.context: in prison; maintained accusation against her

prior_accusations.context: accused Catherine of being second in the dance at sabbat, after 'la Stablatte', accompanied by Mre Persin

notable_quotes.speaker: Barbeline veuve Jean Wanier
notable_quotes.french: qu'a la verité elle n'en auseroit point donner, parce que c'estoient brebis qu'elle tenoit de maitre, et avoit tousjours ouy dire, que les brebis debvoient estre gouvernées aussi justement, que les mouches a miel
notable_quotes.english: in truth she would not dare give any, because these were sheep she kept for a master, and had always heard said that sheep should be managed as carefully as bees
notable_quotes.context: refusing to give wool to accused

notable_quotes.speaker: Demenge Perry
notable_quotes.french: Que c'estoit moult mal faict, de gaster ainsi le bien de dieu
notable_quotes.english: That it was very badly done, to waste the goods of God thus
notable_quotes.context: Catherine's rebuke when his horse strayed into her wheat field

notable_quotes.speaker: Colas Avereu
notable_quotes.french: dequoy appercevant, Il considera en soymesme qu'il avoit mal faict d'avoir prins querelle contre ladite Malreannatte, qui n'est entre eulx en aultre estime que d'une sorciere, et pour y remedier, Il luy quicta sa debte se deporta de ladite saisie par luy requise, et luy feit donner du laict, quand elle venoit à sa maison, surquoy sondit cheval se porta bien
notable_quotes.english: perceiving this, he considered within himself that he had done wrong to have taken a quarrel against said Malremmeix, who is held among them in no other estimation than as a witch, and to remedy it, he forgave her debt, withdrew from said seizure he had requested, and had milk given to her when she came to his house, whereupon said horse got well
notable_quotes.context: after his horse became lame following seizure of wheat

notable_quotes.speaker: Mauriche Harauze (Catherine's last husband)
notable_quotes.french: Qu'il estoit grand bruict qu'on vouloit prendre sa femme pour sorciere, et sy daventure, elle estoit apprehendée demandoit s'il auroit ce qu'il vouloit ensemencer sur ladit champ, disant en plus, qu'il se craindoit fort qu'elle estoit sorciere, parce qu'a ceux qui ordinairement l'appeloient sorciere et Genauxe, elle ne laissoit le lendemain leur donner le bon jour, sans aultrement s'en formaliser Qu'il eut beaucoup mieulx valu à luy, le jour qu'il l'esposa, de prendre ung loup par la queue, qui luy eut mange le bras Jusques au coude que d'avoir sa compaignie et que jamais il ne demeureroit avec elle
notable_quotes.english: That there was great rumor that they wanted to take his wife for a witch, and if by chance she was apprehended, asked if he would have what he wanted to sow on said field, saying moreover, that he feared greatly that she was a witch, because to those who ordinarily called her witch and Genauxe, she did not fail the next day to give them good day, without otherwise taking offense. That it would have been much better for him, the day he married her, to take a wolf by the tail, which would have eaten his arm up to the elbow, than to have her company, and that he would never remain with her
notable_quotes.context: told to Didier George le Clerc when contracting to plough a field; husband then went to war and died there

notable_quotes.speaker: Catherine Malremmeix
notable_quotes.french: et quand ung voisin perd, l'autre n'y a pas beaucoup de proffit
notable_quotes.english: and when one neighbor loses, the other doesn't profit much from it
notable_quotes.context: denying she caused death of two sheep

notable_quotes.speaker: Catherine Malremmeix
notable_quotes.french: que le bon dieu ne l'a jusques icy delaissée, par la bonne devotion qu'elle ait heu a luy. Et luy a bien envoyé du bon reconfort
notable_quotes.english: that the good God has not abandoned her up to now, because of the good devotion she has had to Him. And He has indeed sent her good comfort
notable_quotes.context: when asked if God had comforted her in her misery and poverty through visions

notable_quotes.speaker: Catherine Malremmeix
notable_quotes.french: N'a voulu dire, qu'elle at heu rencontre ou bien vision quelconque mais que c'a esté en son esprit qu'elle a esté allegée
notable_quotes.english: Did not want to say that she had encounter or any vision but that it was in her spirit that she was relieved
notable_quotes.context: refusing to describe how God comforted her

notable_quotes.speaker: Laurence, wife of George Tolbay
notable_quotes.french: Et a advisé et exhorté ladite Malremmatte de ne se faire rudier comme elle a faict que ce n'est que rosée, des presens interrogats
notable_quotes.english: And advised and exhorted said Malremmeix not to let herself be roughed up as she has done, that it is only dew, these present interrogations

notable_quotes.speaker: Catherine Malremmeix
notable_quotes.french: que les fortunes viennent comme Dieu les envoye
notable_quotes.english: that misfortunes come as God sends them
notable_quotes.context: reply to Jean de Wanemont during confrontations

notable_quotes.speaker: Didier George le Clerc
notable_quotes.french: qu'au diable soit le poulain et son maitre
notable_quotes.english: to the devil with the foal and its master
notable_quotes.context: chasing out foal belonging to Catherine's son that got into his field

relationships.evidence_text: currently married to Mauriche Harauze, who had gone to the war

economic_context.details: Multiple debts mentioned: Catherine owed debt to Colas Avereu (3 bichots of wheat); Claudon George owed Catherine a resal of wheat as rent for a field; Jean Perry's dispute over who owed whom money for labor; Catherine's poverty mentioned as reason husband went to war. Property disputes include dispute over guard of 'la harde des fosses' and field ownership.

harms_catalog.harm_description: sudden blow on leg, fell to ground, unable to walk for 8 days, felt after-effects for a year
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: refused to relinquish guard of 'la harde des fosses'

harms_catalog.harm_description: fell ill, trouble beginning at soles of feet, languished miserably for 18 months, showed evident signs of being bewitched, threw up spiders and other living creatures from mouth and nostrils near death
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: same quarrel over guard of harde

harms_catalog.victim_name: child of Jehennon and Claudon George
harms_catalog.harm_description: fell ill at noon and was dead by evening
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: dispute over payment of wheat rent

harms_catalog.harm_description: became lame in one leg; recovered after he forgave debt and gave her milk
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: seized wheat from Claudon George to pay debt accused owed him

harms_catalog.harm_description: became ill next day and soon died
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: horse strayed into field where she was reaping

harms_catalog.harm_description: two of best sheep died
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: refused to give wool for 'un bas de chausse'

harms_catalog.harm_description: died suddenly
became ill, still in poor state, unable to support itself on its legs
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: dispute over payment for husband's labor in hay harvest

harms_catalog.harm_description: horses bolted in fright for no reason, ran into man with sickle, one horse had leg 'couppée' by sickle
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: refused to loan horse to bring fruit from Malreanneix

harms_catalog.harm_description: fine calf died
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: wife refused loan of 'fillet' and other things

harms_catalog.harm_description: fine cow lost
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Catherine's son left him 'un veillon de maitre' against her will

harms_catalog.harm_description: largest piglet died, followed next day by two next largest
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: she wanted largest piglet as payment, he gave her middling one
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: as soon as she had taken the piglet

harms_catalog.victim_name: bull of Didier George le Clerc
harms_catalog.harm_description: became as if rabid, returned home unable to stand
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: foal belonging to her son got into his field; he chased it out cursing

harms_catalog.victim_name: child of Claudon George (5 years old)
harms_catalog.harm_description: fell ill at noon and was dead by evening

harms_catalog.victim_name: cow of Catherine femme Mongeon Valentin
harms_catalog.harm_description: fine cow and two calves it was carrying lost
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: refused to sell the accused some oats

harms_catalog.victim_name: unknown animal of Catherine femme Mongeon Valentin
harms_catalog.harm_description: another loss (word missing in document)
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: refused loan of salt for cooking

harms_catalog.victim_name: sheep of Magdelaine femme Jean Wanemont
harms_catalog.harm_description: lost a sheep

harms_catalog.victim_name: cow of Magdelaine femme Jean Wanemont
harms_catalog.harm_description: lost cow
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: accused's son left lease of another cow

harms_catalog.victim_name: horse of Magdelaine femme Jean Wanemont
harms_catalog.harm_description: accident with scythe
three times had 'grand travail d'enfant' and aborted

material_culture.context: Catherine needed these and bought them at market when needed
measure of oats refused to accused
given to Catherine when she came to house (to remedy curse)
payment for reaping work; seven piglets, she wanted largest
asked to borrow along with other things
man carrying on shoulder; horse injured by it
carting from fields, bringing horses back to village
measure of wheat owed as rent

spatial_references.context: primary location of trial; residence of accused and most witnesses
origin of witness 1, now living at St. Margarée
location of wife of Colas Cui (named accomplice)
origin of Claudon George, living at Sainct Margerée
Catherine asked to borrow horse to bring fruit from this village
location where sabbat was held; agreed at last Easter to make hail to spoil grain crop
guarding 'la harde', reaping wheat, carting from fields, foal getting into field
guard duty that was subject of dispute

historical_context.military_details: Catherine's husband Mauriche Harauze went to war voluntarily at St. George's day because they were poor and he could not provide 'en rencons'; Didier George le Clerc reported husband said he would never remain with Catherine and went to war where he died
economic_hardship_indicators: poverty mentioned - husband went to war because poor and could not provide
disputes over small amounts of grain and wool
Catherine bought stockings at market when needed
religious_calendar_references: Christmas (a year ago at previous Christmas)

prior_legal_disputes.description: Multiple debt disputes: wheat owed to Catherine; Catherine's debt to Colas Avereu; dispute over who owed money between Catherine's husband and Jean Perry

emotional_state_notes: lost power of speech when Laurence made accusation
begged judges to have pity and not force her to say things that were not true
became silent during torture except to say God was her master

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Made no objection to any witness during confrontations
Said accusation from Laurence came from hatred because she wouldn't give her daughter to Laurence's son, and Laurence had threatened her on this occasion

third_parties.name: Mauriche Harauze
third_parties.context: went to war at St. George's day because of poverty; gave detailed testimony about his fear she was a witch and regret at marrying her; died in war

third_parties.name: Catherine's children
third_parties.context: debts were owed by her children

third_parties.name: Catherine's son
third_parties.context: his foal got into Didier George's field; left lease of cow to Jean Wanemont against Catherine's will

third_parties.name: daughter of Mengeatte (marriageable age)
third_parties.context: fell ill and died after 18 months of languishing; showed signs of bewitchment

third_parties.name: la Stablatte
third_parties.context: first in the dance at sabbat according to Laurence's accusation

third_parties.name: Mre Persin
third_parties.context: took her to sabbat; accompanied her in dance; presence behind her ear caused silence

third_parties.name: man carrying sickle
third_parties.context: horses bolted and ran into him; one horse's leg cut by his sickle

extraction_metadata.notes: Complete trial record with detailed witness testimonies, confession under torture, multiple named accomplices, and typical pattern of quarrel-harm-reputation. Notable features include husband's dramatic statement about preferring a wolf to her company before going to war and dying; the remedial actions taken by Colas Avereu (forgiving debt, giving milk) to reverse curse; and Catherine's eventual partial retraction of accusations. Trial shows extensive economic disputes over small amounts (grain, wool, animal feed) and numerous animal deaths attributed to witchcraft following petty quarrels.
